Hi Joel,

Novelty search is one really inspiring idea. 
It is interesting t=
o note that when I added the dynamic adjustment of 
the sparseness/novelty =
score, the performance was actually worse than 
without adjusting the novel=
ty score, i.e. an individual always stays 
with the novelty score it was bo=
rn with. 
I hypothesize that this is because it encourages such species tha=
t 
produce more novel behaviors frequently. But I guess that the best 
way =
is to recompute the novelty scores at regular intervals.. 

Peter

--- In n=
eat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <lehman.154@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Peter,
> 
> G=
lad to hear that you are interested in the method, and that you've
> been a=
ble to implement it.
> 
> You are correct, the novelty of each individual i=
s calculated with
> respect to the current population and the archive.
> 
>=
 Yes, sparseness in the behavioral space around an individual is
> equated =
with novelty, which is used for the fitness of the 
individual.
> 
> Ideall=
y, novelty would recomputed for each individual in the current
> generation=
 after each evaluation. In our implementation it is 
allowed
> to get stale=
 for a few evaluations (in the same frequency that
> individuals are respec=
iated according to rtNEAT). In our 
experiments,
> allowing for a bit stale=
ness did not effect the results.
> 
> Actually, in the scenario you describ=
e, each of the individuals 
would
> now have a lower novelty, the original =
individual included. This
> reflects that the area around these individuals=
 in behavior space is
> more dense than it previously was. As more individu=
als come into a
> particular area, the novelty of all of them drops, and pr=
ovides
> pressure for individuals to do something new in order to be seen a=
s 
novel.
> 
> Let me know if you have any more implementation questions, I=
'll be
> releasing my source based off the rtNEAT package in the next few 
=
weeks.
> 
> Joel 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <pet=
ar_chervenski@>
> wrote:
> >
> > Hello,
> > 
> > I implemented novelty sear=
ch and the maze navigation task (it 
> > works! :)), but I need to ask you =
about something. 
> > 
> > So when a new individual is spawned from the pop=
ulation, its 
novelty is 
> > computed based on the domain-specific distanc=
e measure to all 
other 
> > behaviors in the population and the archive, r=
ight. 
> > 
> > But what about the population itself, should every individu=
al 
there 
> > recompute its sparseness on every evaluation, based on the n=
ew 
> > circumstances? 
> > 
> > I ask this because when I observe the spar=
seness (I assume 
sparseness 
> > equals fitness) of the individuals, say o=
ne happens to be in a 
very 
> > sparse area so it receives a high fitness =
score. But then a 
couple of 
> > other individuals come into this area, so=
 it becomes more dense. 
But 
> > that first individual still has a high fi=
tness score? Is this 
right? 
> > 
> > Peter
> >
>
